page.title: 08Keswick's market
page.content: In 1300 Thomas De Derwentwater proved his right to have a market at his Manor of Keswick and was given permission by King Edward I.The trade the market first attracted was corn and provisions.There was a cattle market on Oct II and a Rams and cheese on the Saturday after the 29th Oct.We intervied a talkative fishman.He said they don't make as much money now.The rents have gone up from Â£20 to Â£75.The price of petrol has gone up which affects the stall holders, so does inflation.The market is now closed to cars so other people have tried to put up more cheap stalls but the shopkeepers objected.The stallholders also said Bank holidays and Whit holidays are no good for business because people dont come to buy food. They are staying in hotels or guest houses.
